name: NodeJS by Namastedev
description: Comprehensive Node.js course by namastedev covering fundamentals to advanced backend development, including Express, MongoDB, authentication, real-time features, and production deployment

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 00: Welcome to NamasteNodeJS
topics.description: Introduction to the course, roadmap, and what you'll learn in this comprehensive NodeJS journey
learningTip: NodeJS enables JavaScript on the server - same language, different environment
Understanding the fundamentals will make everything else click
Focus on the 'why' behind NodeJS design decisions
Practice by building small utilities and scripts
mustNotMiss: NodeJS is NOT a language - it's a runtime environment for JavaScript
Built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine for high performance
Non-blocking I/O is the core design principle
NPM (Node Package Manager) is the world's largest software registry

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 01: Introduction to NodeJS
topics.description: Understanding what NodeJS is, its history, and why it's revolutionary for JavaScript development
learningTip: NodeJS was created by Ryan Dahl in 2009 to handle concurrent connections
Single-threaded but non-blocking - handles many connections efficiently
Perfect for I/O heavy applications (APIs, real-time apps)
Not ideal for CPU-intensive tasks (video encoding, ML)
mustNotMiss: NodeJS runs JavaScript outside the browser
Uses event-driven, non-blocking I/O model
process object provides info about current Node process
global object in Node is like window in browser

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 02: JS on Server
topics.description: Understanding how JavaScript runs on the server-side and the differences from client-side execution
learningTip: Browser has window, DOM, fetch - Node has process, fs, http
Node adds server capabilities JavaScript never had
Same language, different built-in objects and APIs
console.log works the same - outputs to terminal instead of browser
mustNotMiss: No window or document objects in NodeJS
process.argv gives command line arguments
process.env contains environment variables
__dirname and __filename give current file path info

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 03: Let's write code
topics.description: Writing your first NodeJS programs and understanding the development workflow
learningTip: node filename.js runs your code - simple and direct
Use nodemon for auto-restart during development
REPL mode: just type 'node' for interactive console
Debug with console.log or use --inspect flag for Chrome DevTools
mustNotMiss: node index.js runs the file
npm init -y creates package.json quickly
npm install --save-dev nodemon for development
package.json scripts: 'start': 'node index.js'

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 04: module.export & require
topics.description: Understanding NodeJS module system, exports, and require mechanism
learningTip: CommonJS: require/module.exports - the Node standard
ES Modules: import/export - modern JavaScript standard
Each file is a module with its own scope
Module caching: require() caches on first load
mustNotMiss: module.exports = function() {} exports the function
const fn = require('./myModule') imports it
exports is shorthand for module.exports (but can't reassign)
For ES modules: add 'type': 'module' in package.json

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 05: Diving into the NodeJS github repo
topics.description: Exploring NodeJS source code, understanding its architecture and contribution process
learningTip: NodeJS is open source - you can read the actual implementation
C++ handles low-level operations, JS provides the API
Understanding internals helps debug complex issues
Contributing to open source is great for learning and career
mustNotMiss: lib/ folder contains JavaScript implementation
src/ folder contains C++ bindings
deps/ contains dependencies like V8, libuv, OpenSSL
Good first issues are tagged for new contributors

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 06: libuv & async IO
topics.description: Deep dive into libuv library and asynchronous I/O operations in NodeJS
learningTip: libuv provides the async I/O - Node's secret sauce
It's a C library that handles file system, network, timers
Abstracts OS differences (Windows vs Linux)
This is why Node can be non-blocking
mustNotMiss: libuv provides the event loop implementation
Thread pool handles file system and DNS operations
Network I/O uses OS-level async primitives (epoll, kqueue)
Default thread pool size is 4 (UV_THREADPOOL_SIZE)

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 07: sync, async, setTimeoutZero - code
topics.description: Understanding synchronous vs asynchronous code execution and timeout mechanisms
learningTip: Sync operations block - the whole server waits
Async operations use callbacks/promises - server continues
setTimeout(fn, 0) doesn't run immediately - goes to event loop
Promises and async/await are cleaner than callbacks
mustNotMiss: fs.readFileSync blocks, fs.readFile is async
setTimeout(fn, 0) runs after current code and microtasks
Promise callbacks run before setTimeout (microtask queue)
process.nextTick runs before Promise.then

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 08: Deep dive into v8 JS Engine
topics.description: Understanding V8 JavaScript engine, compilation, and optimization processes
learningTip: V8 compiles JavaScript to machine code (JIT compilation)
Hidden classes optimize object property access
Garbage collection is automatic but understand its impact
Use --v8-options to see all V8 flags
mustNotMiss: V8 compiles JS to native machine code, not bytecode
TurboFan optimizer makes hot code faster
Memory limit: ~1.5GB on 64-bit (adjustable with --max-old-space-size)
Garbage collection pauses can affect latency

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 09: libuv & Event Loop
topics.description: Comprehensive understanding of the event loop and its phases
learningTip: Event loop is the heartbeat of NodeJS
It processes callbacks in specific phases in order
Understanding phases helps predict execution order
Don't block the event loop - use worker threads for CPU work
mustNotMiss: Phases: timers → pending callbacks → poll → check → close
process.nextTick runs between phases (before microtasks)
Promise.then runs in microtask queue (after nextTick)
setImmediate runs in check phase (after poll)

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 10: Thread pool in libuv
topics.description: Understanding thread pool concepts and their role in NodeJS operations
learningTip: Thread pool handles blocking operations asynchronously
File system, crypto, compression use the thread pool
Network I/O doesn't use thread pool - uses OS async
Increase pool size for I/O heavy apps
mustNotMiss: Default: 4 threads, max: 1024
Set with UV_THREADPOOL_SIZE environment variable
fs, crypto, zlib use thread pool
Too many concurrent file operations can exhaust pool

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 11: Creating a Server
topics.description: Building your first HTTP server using NodeJS built-in modules
learningTip: http module is built-in - no npm install needed
Request and response objects are streams
This is low-level - Express abstracts it nicely
Understand raw http before using frameworks
mustNotMiss: const server = http.createServer((req, res) => {})
req.url and req.method for routing
res.statusCode, res.setHeader(), res.end()
server.listen(3000) starts the server

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 12: Databases - SQL & NoSQL
topics.description: Introduction to databases, understanding SQL vs NoSQL paradigms
learningTip: SQL: structured, relational, ACID compliant (PostgreSQL, MySQL)
NoSQL: flexible schema, horizontal scaling (MongoDB, Redis)
Choose based on data structure and access patterns
Most apps use a combination of both
mustNotMiss: SQL: tables, rows, joins, foreign keys
NoSQL: collections, documents, embedded data
SQL for complex queries and transactions
NoSQL for flexible schema and horizontal scaling

topics.name: Season 1 Episode 13: Creating a database & mongodb
topics.description: Setting up MongoDB and understanding document-based database concepts
learningTip: MongoDB stores JSON-like documents (BSON)
Mongoose provides schema validation and helpful methods
Connection pooling is handled automatically
Use indexes for query performance
mustNotMiss: mongoose.connect('mongodb://localhost:27017/dbname')
const schema = new mongoose.Schema({ name: String })
const Model = mongoose.model('Name', schema)
Model.find(), Model.findById(), Model.create()
